etymologies: late Middle English (denoting a saline substance derived from the ashes of various plants, including glasswort): from medieval Latin, from Arabic al-qalī ‘calcined ashes (of the glasswort etc.)’, from qalā ‘fry, roast’

crossReferenceMarkers: Often contrasted with acid; compare with base
definitions: a chemical compound that neutralizes or effervesces with acids and turns litmus blue; typically, a caustic or corrosive substance of this kind such as lime or soda

examples.text: flint is not subject to chemical weathering except by strong alkalis
the reaction is followed by measuring the concentration of alkali at various times

notes.text: Alkalis release hydroxide ions (OH⁻) when dissolved in water. Any solution with a pH of more than 7 is alkaline

shortDefinitions: compound with particular chemical properties including turning litmus blue
